awd_titl_txt: Superdeep Diamonds from the Transition Zone and Lower Mantle
awd_abstract_narration:
Diamond is a remarkable material for its ultimate physical properties and technological applications. Natural diamonds also reveal physical and chemical processes in the Earth's deep mantle from where there are few direct samples. Mineral inclusions in diamond reflect reactions involving high pressure, high temperature, fluids, melts, and dynamic interactions between the Earth's surface and interior. This project will support technological development to investigate tiny mineral inclusions in diamonds. A new suite of more than 150 diamonds of deep origin, which formed at depths greater than 410 km in the transition zone and the lower mantle, will be investigated. 3D imaging, diffraction, and spectroscopy of the hosted inclusions will be carried out at national X-ray and infrared facilities. Up to a thousand micro-mineral inclusions will be identified and characterized by fast, high-throughput methods. Results of this research will improve our understanding of the mineral diversity in the Earth's interior, with special focus on water and hydrous phases. The goal is to reveal the mechanisms by which water recycles between the crust and mantle through plate tectonics, a process at the origin of numerous natural hazards. This project will foster collaboration with two local high-school teachers to introduce a geophysics curriculum to their physics courses. It will also promote the training of several graduate students for future careers in academia, federal agencies, industry, and the national laboratories.   

The high strength and stability of diamond make it a perfect vessel for transporting minerals and geochemical information from the deep mantle to the surface as part of the crust-mantle carbon cycle. This study will examine a new suite of superdeep diamonds from Juina, Brazil, which host mineral inclusions from the transition zone and lower mantle. One of the major challenges pertains to determining the depth origin of the diamonds which often lack a complete suite of mineral inclusions to pinpoint their formation conditions. Up to a thousand inclusions will be analyzed potentially promoting the discovery of new mineral phases and providing information about how deeply water is transported into the mantle. New micro-analysis techniques will increase the rate and decrease the size of inclusions that can be studied, thus broadening the database of mantle mineralogy. Spectroscopic methods will probe various types of atomic-scale defects in diamonds as tracers for their depth of origin. Separately, the sound velocity of diamond will be measured at high pressure in all directions of the structure to determine diamond elastic properties. This will improve the geophysical modeling of seismic wave velocity in the deep, crustal roots below continents. Other experiments will examine the decompression behavior of hydrous minerals at upper mantle temperatures to elucidate diamond ascent pathways. Ultimately this research will improve and potentially modify the textbook picture of the structure and dynamics of Earth's interior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Diamonds are admired by people around the world for their beauty, but they also hold scientific value as rugged containers of geochemical information from the mysterious underworld beneath our feet, far beyond the reach of any drill. Diamonds are a high-pressure form of pure carbon, which were brought to the surface in ancient volcanic eruptions. Whereas most diamonds formed the deep lithosphere about a hundred kilometers (km) below the surface, some diamonds, known as superdeep diamonds, may derive from many hundreds of km depth based on the unusual mineral impurities found within them, called inclusions. Mineral inclusions are generally unwanted in diamond by the gem industry, but such inclusions can provide a wealth of scientific information about the composition of the Earth’s deep mantle and its connection to the dynamic surface we live on. Analyzing the tiny inclusions found inside superdeep diamonds without breaking them open has been a challenge for the scientific community.  

This proposal focused on developing analytical laboratory methods to determine the identity and composition of tiny mineral inclusions found within diamonds. A new suite of superdeep diamonds from Juina, Brazil, was made available through collaborations with scientists in the US and Canada. Using brilliant and highly-focused X-rays produced by the US Department of Energy at a facility called the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, instrumentation and routines were established to rapidly process dozens of mineral inclusions in a fraction of the time that was required prior to this work. Part of the challenge is that some mineral inclusions are only a few micrometers in size, being a hundred times thinner than a human hair, and they are buried deep with the diamonds. The research performed under this award focused on non-destructive testing, meaning that the inclusions did not need to be broken out of the diamond, but rather studied in place.

Results found that most inclusions in this set of diamonds are iron oxides with magnesium, occurring in the same crystal structure as rocksalt. That mineral, (Mg,Fe)O, also known as ferropericlase, is thought to be a major constituent of the Earth’s deep mantle, further indicating the deep origin of these stones. While some of the inclusions were captured from the mantle during diamond growth, some were clearly growing along with the diamonds, indicating that extreme oxidation-reduction reactions occur in carbonate melts derived from the Earth’s surface during diamond growth in the mantle as part of the global carbon cycle.

In addition to iron-magnesium oxides, the team found numerous other minerals including titanium-bearing iron oxides, garnets, olivine, and even a few zircons that could be used for dating such diamonds in the future. The developed methods also facilitated determining the crystal orientation of the inclusions with respect to the diamond hosts, allowing for distinction between minerals formed during diamond formation versus those captured from the deep mantle. In a diamond from Koffiefontein, South Africa, the team co-discovered a previously unknown mineral containing the rare earth oxide called niobium (Nb). The new potassium niobate mineral was named goldschmidtite and indicates highly evolved reactions between crustal fluids with the deep mantle.

To address one of the major questions surrounding superdeep diamonds, in particular from how deep to they come, the team used laboratory methods to synthesize some of the minerals found within superdeep diamonds and subjected those samples to pressures and temperatures close to predicted diamond formation conditions. By modelling the compressive behavior of those minerals at high temperature, and developing so-called equations of state for those minerals, it will be possible for researchers to back-out the formation depth of superdeep diamonds in future studies.

Professional development activities were focused on training graduate students in analytical methods used at the US national laboratories to investigate the properties of materials at extreme conditions, with applications ranging from the design and synthesis of energy-related materials to national security.
